1449142120527417348.text:
Our job as lawmakers is to make this possible by:
-Passing transformational water policies
-Working with our Tribes and Pueblos & Communities
-Investing in our water management agencies
-Investing in resilient infrastructure and
-Protecting our rivers.

1449142118602231811.text:
As we look to the future and managing these river systems in a time of change we must:
🤝Leverage partnerships
⚛️Invest in science and technology
🚰Modernize our infrastructure and operations, and
👨‍👧‍👧Ensure our communities are at the table and helping to drive decisions.

1449142116517560329.text: Climate change is here. And it is threatening the ability of our communities to bring water to our fields, to meet the needs of our Tribes and Pueblos, acequias, farmers and ranchers, and our rivers – which depend on these life-giving waters.

1449142114676322308.text: Nowhere is this more visible than in New Mexico, where our communities have faced historic drought conditions at the same time our state has grappled with its highest number of emergency declarations due to flooding and wildfires this year.

1449142112860188672.text: But it is clear that what we are seeing today is part of a much larger trend of a changing climate—as temperatures are getting hotter, our snowpack is declining, and we are seeing fundamental changes in our hydrologic systems.

1449142110968500226.text: Our rivers have been gripped by drought across the West this year. But our communities are no strangers to water scarcity, as our Tribes and Pueblos have lived on these lands since time immemorial and our land grant and acequia communities have shared water across generations.

1449142108837777415.text: Addressing drought and water resilience in the West requires that we take #ClimateActionNow and make transformational investments in our communities and rivers. Here's why 👇https://t.co/SwwadbJlTs
